title: Question 166

children: A 65-year-old asymptomatic man is evaluated after screening abdominal ultrasonography for aortic aneurysm revealed diffuse thickening of the gallbladder wall. The gallbladder examination was negative for gallbladder wall calcification, stones, polyps, and masses. The patient has never experienced gallbladder or biliary tract symptoms.
Physical examination is normal. Complete blood count and liver chemistry test results are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

For the diagnosis of gallbladder cancer, cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI is generally preferred because of the additional ability to detect liver involvement and the presence of regional lymph node and distant metastases, which will inform treatment decisions.
The initial treatment for gallbladder cancer is cholecystectomy.

) for this patient with an ultrasound finding of diffuse thickening of the gallbladder wall, which is concerning for gallbladder cancer. Gallbladder cancer, the most common cancer of the biliary tree, is rare, with an observed frequency of less than 0.001%. Patients with early invasive gallbladder cancer may have no symptoms or may present with episodic right-upper-quadrant abdominal pain or biliary colic. Risk factors include gallstones, porcelain gallbladder (intramural calcification of the gallbladder wall), gallbladder polyps, and primary sclerosing cholangitis. The potential resectability of this lesion should be evaluated with MRI and MRCP. The extent of local invasion can be evaluated, and the distinction between benign and malignant lesions potentially can be made. The initial treatment for gallbladder cancer is cholecystectomy. Tumors that extend beyond the lamina propria require extended cholecystectomy. If the tumor is found to be unresectable, chemotherapy with or without radiation therapy or palliative care can be considered.
